messageBody:
Peter O'Neill wrote:
> I am hoping to test that all the attributes in the database can be set
> and that someone hasn't unwittingly changed a particular attribute to
> read-only. It would seem to be overkill to have a test method for each
> of the hundreds of attributes. So i currently do the following,
>
> - add a failure to a testResult
> - fail if the testResult failureCount > 0
> - print out all the failures
>
> If anyone can help me with a better approach I would be grateful.

Hmmm.... how 'bout something like this:

// Standard warning: I'm building it from memory, there may be typoes or
misnamed methods
class AttributeTester extends junit.framework.TestCase {
private final String attributeToTest;

public AttributeTester(String name, String attributeToTest) {
super(name);
this.attributeToTest = attributeToTest;
}

public junit.framework.Test suite() {
junit.framework.TestSuite theSuite = new junit.framework.TestSuite();
// Create a an array of the attributes here
for (int i = 0; i < attributes.length; i++) {
theSuite.addTest(new AttributeTester("testAttribute",
attributes[i]);
}
return theSuite;
}

public void testAttribute() {
// ensure that this.attributeToTest is not read-only.
}
}

You may also want to override toString() so that you can report the failing
attribute in the error message.

For bonus points, pull in the list of attributes dynamically somehow
(perhaps directly from the database, or from the script used to build the
database).

Robert.
